clinical_study.brief_title: Control of Major Bleeding After Trauma Study
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective, Randomized Comparison of Fresh Frozen Plasma Versus Standard Crystalloid Intravenous Fluid as Initial Resuscitation Fluid

collaborator.agency: U.S. Army Medical Research and Development Command

brief_summary.textblock: Bleeding is the most avoidable cause of death in trauma patients. Up to one-third of severely injured trauma patients are found to be coagulopathic and forty percent of the mortality following severe injury is due to uncontrollable hemorrhage in the setting of coagulopathy. It has been established that early administration of fresh frozen plasma decreases mortality following severe injury, replacing lost coagulation factors, improving the coagulopathy and restoring blood volume. This study will determine if giving plasma to severely injured trauma patients during ambulance transport versus after arrival to the hospital will help reduce hemorrhage, thus decreasing both total blood product administration and mortality.

detailed_description.textblock: Study Design: Severely injured trauma patients with a systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 70 or SBP ≤ 90 with a heart rate ≥ 108 bpm at the scene will be enrolled and randomized to receive either 2 units of frozen plasma thawed in the field or normal saline (the current standard of care), as the initial resuscitation fluid. After this initial resuscitation fluid, both groups will receive the same standard of care, including packed red blood cells, additional normal saline, or plasma as needed based on laboratory and clinical evidence of coagulopathy. Blood samples and clinical information will be collected throughout the hospital stay up to 28 days after injury.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants That Died Within 28 Days Post Injury
primary_outcome.description: death within 28 days post injury (death of any cause except for death due to a second, clearly unrelated traumatic injury suffered after discharge)

secondary_outcome.measure: Composite Outcome of 28-day In-hospital Mortality and Postinjury Multiple Organ Failure (MOF) Incidence
secondary_outcome.description: The occurrence of in-hospital death or MOF within the first 28 days postinjury. MOF is defined using the validated Denver MOF score (Denver MOF score>3 of simultaneously obtained scores after 48 hours postinjury).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: within 30 minutes of Emergency Department (ED) arrival
secondary_outcome.description: Defined as the first international normalized ratio (INR) obtained upon ED arrival. The international normalized ratio (INR) is an international standard for the prothrombin time (PT). This measures the time it takes for blood to clot. The normal range for a healthy person is 0.83-1.19. Usually, a high INR indicates a higher risk of bleeding, while a low INR suggests a higher risk of developing a clot.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Admission Severe Coagulopathy
secondary_outcome.time_frame: within 30 minutes of Emergency Department (ED) arrival
secondary_outcome.description: Defined as international normalized ratio (INR) >1.3 obtained upon ED arrival. The international normalized ratio (INR) is an international standard for the prothrombin time (PT). This measures the time it takes for blood to clot. The normal range for a healthy person is 0.83-1.19. Usually, a high INR indicates a higher risk of bleeding, while a low INR suggests a higher risk of developing a clot.
Admission clot strength will be measured by thrombelastography G-value upon ED arrival. Clot strength measured in kilodynes per square centimetre (kdyn/cm^2).
Admission acidosis measured by lactate upon ED arrival.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Admission Severe Acidosis
secondary_outcome.description: Admission severe acidosis measured by lactate>5 upon ED arrival.
Admission acidosis will be defined by base deficit (BD) upon ED arrival.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Admission Severe Acidosis
secondary_outcome.description: Admission severe acidosis will be defined by base deficit (BD>10) upon ED arrival.

other_outcome.measure: Baseline (Field) Coagulation Factor Levels
other_outcome.time_frame: after injury and prior to hospital arrival, at about 15 minutes after injury
other_outcome.description: defined as the first coagulation factor level obtained in the field prior to intervention Coagulation Factor Reference Ranges F2 F5 F7 F8 F9 F11 % % % % % % 67.0 - 107.0 63.0 - 116.0 52.0 - 120.0 58.0 - 132.0 47.0 - 122.0 52.0 - 120.0

other_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Abnormal Baseline (Field) Coagulation Factor XIII Level
other_outcome.time_frame: after injury prior to hospital arrival
other_outcome.description: defined as abnormal coagulation factor XIII level obtained in the field prior to intervention

other_outcome.measure: Admission (First Arrival) Coagulation Factor Levels
other_outcome.time_frame: after injury prior to hospital arrival
other_outcome.description: defined as the first coagulation factor level obtained upon ED arrival Coagulation Factor Reference Ranges F2 F5 F7 F8 F9 F11 % % % % % % 67.0 - 107.0 63.0 - 116.0 52.0 - 120.0 58.0 - 132.0 47.0 - 122.0 52.0 - 120.0

other_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Abnormal Admission Coagulation Factor XIII (Fibrin-stabilizing Factor) Level
other_outcome.time_frame: within 30 minutes of Emergency Department (ED) arrival
other_outcome.description: defined as the first abnormal factor XIII (fibrin-stabilizing factor) level obtained upon ED arrival

other_outcome.description: Number of participants with 24-hour mortality, adverse outcome free days and transfusions

other_outcome.measure: Exploratory Analyses.

other_outcome.measure: Number of Adverse Outcome Free Days in a Sub-group With Severe Hemorrhagic Shock

other_outcome.measure: Exploratory Analyses in a Sub-group With Severe Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)
other_outcome.description: Number of participants with 28-day mortality. Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is defined as Abbreviated Injury Score (AIS) for Head/Neck >=3.

other_outcome.description: Number of participants with severe adverse events (SAE)

other_outcome.measure: Haemoglobin (Hb) Level in a Sub-group With Severe Hemorrhagic Shock

other_outcome.measure: Blood Product Transfusion in a Sub-group With Severe Hemorrhagic Shock
other_outcome.description: Number of blood products transfused in units in the patients with initial systolic blood pressure (SBP) <=70 mmHg

other_outcome.measure: Time to Admission and First Blood Transfusion in a Sub-group With Severe Hemorrhagic Shock
other_outcome.description: Time to Admission and First Blood Transfusion in the patients with initial systolic blood pressure (SBP) <=70 mmHg

other_outcome.measure: Haemoglobin (Hb) Level
other_outcome.description: Haemoglobin (Hb) level in g/dL units.

other_outcome.measure: Number of Blood Products Transfused.
other_outcome.description: Number of blood products transfused in units.

other_outcome.measure: Time to Admission and First Blood Transfusion
other_outcome.description: Time to admission and first blood product transfusion in minutes.

arm_group.description: If the patient is randomized to experimental arm, 2 units of frozen type AB plasma (FP24) will be thawed in the Plasmatherm Dry Thawing and Warming Device according to the operator manual as approved by the FDA in the ambulance and infusion will commence as soon as the type AB plasma is ready, and will continue during transport to the emergency department (ED). After infusion of 2 units of type AB plasma is completed, subsequent care will proceed per institutional, Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guided resuscitation with acute packed red blood cells (pRBC) administration determined by the hemodynamic response and additional blood component administration guided by rapid thrombelastography (rTEG) and coagulation panel assessment in conjunction with clinical scenario.

If the patient is randomized to the standard arm, the patient will be given intravenous crystalloid fluid (normal saline) as the initial resuscitation fluid with 2 large bore IVs based on the current ATLS guidelines, the standard of care. Subsequent care will proceed per institutional, ATLS guided resuscitation with acute packed red blood cells pRBC administration determined by the hemodynamic response and additional blood component administration guided by rTEG and coagulation panel assessment in conjunction with clinical scenario.

intervention.description: The plasma is thawed and administered to subjects in the experimental (plasma) arm.

intervention.intervention_name: Crystalloid fluid (standard of care for resuscitation)
intervention.description: Normal saline will be give to subjects in the standard arm as the current standard of care for an initial resuscitation fluid

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age>=18 years
- Acutely injured
- SBP<70 mmHg or SBP 71-90 mmHg with heart rate (HR)>108 beats per minute.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Visibly or verbally reported pregnant women
- known prisoners
- unsalvageable injuries (defined as asystolic or cardiopulmonary resuscitation prior to randomization)
- known objection to blood products
- the patient has an opt-out bracelet or, necklace or wallet card
- a family member present at the scene objects to the patient's enrollment in research.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Professor and Vice Chair, Department of Surgery

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: The enrollment and randomization occurred almost simultaneously. Once the paramedics determined the patient to be eligible, the cooler was opened and the randomization was done based on the cooler content: cooler with plasma randomized the patient to the experimental and cooler with frozen water randomized the patient to the control group.

measure.title: Comorbidities
measure.description: Presence of one or more additional diseases or disorders co-occurring in trauma patient.

measure.title: Blunt injury mechanism
measure.description: Blunt force trauma is an injury that occurs when an object hits or strikes a part of the body.

measure.title: New Injury Severity Scale (NISS)
measure.description: The New Injury Severity Score (NISS) is an anatomical scoring system that provides an overall score for patients with multiple injuries. This is calculated as the sum of the squares of the top three Abbreviated Injury Scores (AIS) regardless of body region. AIS is an anatomical-based coding system on a scale of one to six, one being a minor injury and six being maximal. The NISS score takes values from 0 to 75. This score is virtually the only anatomical scoring system in use and correlates linearly with mortality, morbidity, hospital stay and other measures of severity.

measure.title: Maximal Abbreviated Injury Score (AIS) for head and neck
measure.description: Abbreviated Injury Score is an anatomical-based coding system on a scale of one to six, one being a minor injury and six being maximal.

measure.title: Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) defined as AIS head >=3
Maximal Abbreviated Injury Score (AIS) chest
measure.description: Abbreviated Injury Score is an anatomical-based coding system on a scale of one to six, one being a minor injury and six being maximal.

measure.title: Maximal Abbreviated Injury Score (AIS) abdomen and pelvis
measure.description: Abbreviated Injury Score is an anatomical-based coding system on a scale of one to six, one being a minor injury and six being maximal.

measure.title: Maximal Abbreviated Injury Score (AIS) extremities
measure.description: Abbreviated Injury Score is an anatomical-based coding system on a scale of one to six, one being a minor injury and six being maximal.

measure.title: Systolic blood pressure (SBP) in the field
Severe shock defined as systolic blood pressure (SBP) in the field <=70mmHg
Body temperature in the field
measure.population: The body temperature was measured in the field with a temporal scanner infrared thermometer. Due to the specifics of the study (acute trauma setting), it was not always possible to obtain a body temperature reading in the field (accident scene).

measure.title: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) in the field
measure.description: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is a neurological scale which aims to give a reliable and objective way of recording the conscious state of a person for initial as well as subsequent assessment. The GCS is the summation of scores for eye, verbal, and motor responses. The minimum score is a 3 which indicates deep coma or a brain-dead state. The maximum is 15 which indicates a fully awake patient.

measure.title: Haemoglobin (Hb) in the field
measure.population: Due to the specifics of the study (acute trauma setting) it was not always possible to obtain a blood sample in the field (accident scene).

measure.title: Platelet count in the field
measure.population: Due to the specifics of the study (acute trauma setting) it was not always possible to obtain a blood sample in the field (accident scene).

measure.population: Due to the specifics of the study (acute trauma setting) it was not always possible to obtain a blood sample in the field (accident scene).

After infusion of 2 units of Type AB plasma is completed, subsequent care will proceed per institutional, Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guided resuscitation with acute packed red blood cells (pRBC) administration determined by hemodynamic response and additional blood component administration guided by rapid thrombelastography (rTEG) and coagulation panel assessment in conjunction with clinical scenario. Type AB plasma: The plasma is thawed and administered to subjects in the experimental (plasma) arm.

group.title: Standard
group.description: If the patient is randomized to the standard arm, the patient will be given intravenous crystalloid fluid (normal saline) as the initial resuscitation fluid with 2 large bore IVs based on the current ATLS guidelines, the standard of care. Subsequent care will proceed per institutional, ATLS guided resuscitation with acute pRBC administration determined by hemodynamic response and additional blood component administration guided by rTEG and coagulation panel assessment in conjunction with clinical scenario. Crystalloid fluid (standard of care for resuscitation): Normal saline will be give to subjects in the standard arm as the current standard of care for an initial resuscitation fluid

measure.title: Admission Acidosis
measure.description: Admission acidosis will be defined by base deficit (BD) upon ED arrival.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Admission Severe Acidosis
outcome.description: Admission severe acidosis will be defined by base deficit (BD>10) upon ED arrival.

measure.description: Number of participants with 28-day mortality. Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is defined as Abbreviated Injury Score (AIS) for Head/Neck >=3.

outcome.title: Severe Adverse Events (SAE)
outcome.description: Number of participants with severe adverse events (SAE)

group.title: Plasma
group.description: If the patient is randomized to experimental arm, 2 units of frozen Type AB plasma (FP24) will be thawed in the Plasmatherm Dry Thawing and Warming Device according to the operator manual as approved by the FDA in the ambulance and infusion will commence as soon as the Type AB plasma is ready, and will continue during transport to the ED. After infusion of 2 units of Type AB plasma is completed, subsequent care will proceed per institutional, Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guided resuscitation with acute packed red blood cells (pRBC) administration determined by hemodynamic response and additional blood component administration guided by rapid thrombelastography (rTEG) and coagulation panel assessment in conjunction with clinical scenario. Type AB plasma: The plasma is thawed and administered to subjects in the experimental (plasma) arm.

group.title: Standard
group.description: If the patient is randomized to the standard arm, the patient will be given intravenous crystalloid fluid (normal saline) as the initial resuscitation fluid with 2 large bore IVs based on the current ATLS guidelines, the standard of care. Subsequent care will proceed per institutional, ATLS guided resuscitation with acute pRBC administration determined by hemodynamic response and additional blood component administration guided by rTEG and coagulation panel assessment in conjunction with clinical scenario. Crystalloid fluid (standard of care for resuscitation): Normal saline will be give to subjects in the standard arm as the current standard of care for an initial resuscitation fluid

group.title: Plasma
group.description: If the patient is randomized to experimental arm, 2 units of frozen Type AB plasma (FP24) will be thawed in the Plasmatherm Dry Thawing and Warming Device according to the operator manual as approved by the FDA in the ambulance and infusion will commence as soon as the Type AB plasma is ready, and will continue during transport to the ED. After infusion of 2 units of Type AB plasma is completed, subsequent care will proceed per institutional, Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guided resuscitation with acute packed red blood cells (pRBC) administration determined by hemodynamic response and additional blood component administration guided by rapid thrombelastography (rTEG) and coagulation panel assessment in conjunction with clinical scenario. Type AB plasma: The plasma is thawed and administered to subjects in the experimental (plasma) arm.

group.title: Standard
group.description: If the patient is randomized to the standard arm, the patient will be given intravenous crystalloid fluid (normal saline) as the initial resuscitation fluid with 2 large bore IVs based on the current ATLS guidelines, the standard of care. Subsequent care will proceed per institutional, ATLS guided resuscitation with acute pRBC administration determined by hemodynamic response and additional blood component administration guided by rTEG and coagulation panel assessment in conjunction with clinical scenario. Crystalloid fluid (standard of care for resuscitation): Normal saline will be give to subjects in the standard arm as the current standard of care for an initial resuscitation fluid

event.description: Organ failure, atrial fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia
Gastrointestinal bleeding and abdominal compartment syndrome
Liver failure and bile duct leak
Acute kidney injury (AKI), kidney failure and renal artery pseudoaneurysm.
Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and lung failure
Delayed hemorrhage from surgical site and torn suture
Deep venous thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE) and pulmonary infarction (PI).

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
